Funny thing, as a kid I was taking cb radios and modded them to run from 4 watts transmission to a almost 10-12 watts. This was with no real education and was early teen, was also self taught how to make and install echo boards, chambers, and install high low freeks as I called them ( in order to slide between frequency of 2 channels) and this was all because of my grandfather buying junk radios and me breaking them just to put them back together 😂

And I have learn over the years, I am highly conductive and I attract electricity. And only learned this when they did a Tesla coil show in the springs, the guy was sitting on the coil and shooting it out of his finger tips. But the arch kept heading to me no matter where he pointed, so the security team escorted my father and I out of the show. I used to love to do demonstrations with the small Tesla coil in my physics classes. The one that seemed to impress my students the most was bringing a long tubular fluorescent light bulb close to the coil and watching it light. I used to tell the students it was my light sabre.

Tesla did more to bring us into the modern age than any other inventor, ever. Just recently he was finally credited with the invention of radio since Marconi used his devices and ideas for his radio broadcast. A list of his inventions and contributions would fill an entire screen. I admire his work as an inventor more than any other person in history.

Tesla was also screwed by Westinghouse. When Westinghouse was on the verge of bankruptcy he gave the company all the stock he owned so they could sell it to gain the capital they needed to survive. Once they were thriving, do you think they gave the stock back to Tesla? The answer should be obvious given the fact that he died in poverty.

It is the current that kills you, however, the Tesla coil can still inflict really bad burns.

TESLA was a genius. He's been a hero of mine for many years. (I'm 78.) Can you show us rf (radio frequency) energy? I'm talking about an amplitude-modulated (AM) wave. This too has been a dream of mine ever since I discovered radio while growing up. Daily I transmit and receive rf at my ham radio station talking and listening to fellow hams around the world, but never have I SEEN what's being said. A moderately sized antenna is just outside our house, but the nature of rf is to remain invisible. The modulated Tesla Coil energy is fun, but I suspect an amplitude-modulated wave would have an entirely different pattern… if only we could see it. Thanks for all the things you do.

Here's the kicker. All Tesla did was LITERALLY NOTHING, compared to what he could've done. When you start reading and researching, you realize that Nikola was going to give us infinite, wireless and free energy all across the globe, with possibilities of audio and video communication, that would put the best smartphones to shame. He was actually working on it, when J.P. Morgan pulled the plug on his research funds, once he realized Tesla will make everything free. If he was allowed to do what he was going to do, he would propelled us straight into the 23rd century, within a decade.
Now just pause for a goddamn moment and imagine the scenario where Tesla was allowed to do what he was intending. No fossil fuels, all vehicles running on wireless, free and super clean energy. No need for phones, wired chargers, you could take your PC out into the woods and start playing video games. Among the other things, he was inventing a military technology so superior, that it would make WARS OBSOLETE, as there could be no winner or loser.
Here's the irony. He died in absolute poverty in a small hotel room in NY, sharing his meals with pigeons.

In order for certain new technology to be expressed, or to be released, there has to be a willingness to receive it. And this requires both the change in the collective consciousness but it also requires that there are certain scientists who are willing to question what most scientists are currently not questioning, including materialism. Now, just as a concrete example here, you have the whole concept of free energy. This can be explained actually in terms of what is currently known by quantum physics. You have observations made by quantum physicists in bubble chambers, that you can have a state where there are no particles, suddenly one particle appears, divides itself into several particles, they collide again and then disappear. There have been some scientists who have been willing to speculate that, beyond what can be observed even at the subatomic level, there must be some kind of energy field, some call it a quantum field, some call it a ground state, whatever they call it, but it has basically been proven by quantum physics, that there is some state beyond the physical material realm. And in that state there is energy. And that energy can then enter the material realm and become physical matter. If you take this and put it together with a big bang, you can see that, is it actually logical that all of the matter and all of the energy that is now in this huge universe was compressed into something called a singularity? Whatever that may be. Is this really logical? Obviously, all of the matchup could not fit in there. But could the energy actually fit into a single point? Is it not just as logical to say that there was an event where energy from a different realm entered the material frequency spectrum. And this means that all of the matter that you see in the world today is actually created from energy. This was proven by Einstein. And that energy must have come from somewhere, and what has now been proven for those who are willing to see it by quantum physics, is that that energy came from another realm. It entered the material world, the physical realm from another realm. Well, is that not free energy? Is it not thereby proven that the entire world is created by free energy? So does that not mean it is also possible that technology could be created, that would be able to, so to speak, channel the energy from a different realm into the material realm, where it could then be used to perform physical work or at least create electricity that could power machines that perform physical work. This is perfectly in line with what has already been discovered. See, what you have right now is, you have a state of technology, which is a reflection of the collective consciousness and the collective consciousness does not really fully accept the existence of another realm. That is why as we have said humankind has become a closed circle, a closed system subject to the second law of thermodynamics. That is why the technology you have today, the energy sources you have today, you think that the only way to provide energy is to either burn some kind of fuel, or split the atom, and free the energy that is already in the material realm. But this is simply a certain mindset that is based on an incomplete understanding of how the world works. As I said, quantum physics has already proven that the world is created by energy from another realm, and therefore, there is naturally much more energy in that realm and it is a matter of raising our view of the world, our understanding of the world, raising the collective consciousness until we can grasp what that other realm is like, and therefore be able to receive the technology that can make use of the energy that is there. It may be not so constructive to talk about free energy, but it is free in a sense that there is no cost, there is nothing that needs to be burned or consumed in the material realm in order to harness this energy and therefore, we might call it a different name and many different names could be suggested.

Every great magic trick consists of three parts or acts. The first part is called "The Pledge". The magician shows you something ordinary: a deck of cards, a bird or a man. He shows you this object. Perhaps he asks you to inspect it to see if it is indeed real, unaltered, normal. But of course... it probably isn't. The second act is called "The Turn". The magician takes the ordinary something and makes it do something extraordinary. Now you're looking for the secret... but you won't find it, because of course you're not really looking. You don't really want to know. You want to be fooled. But you wouldn't clap yet. Because making something disappear isn't enough; you have to bring it back. That's why every magic trick has a third act, the hardest part, the part we call "The Prestige"

I was helping the staff of Survival Research Laboratories (SRL) put on one of their shows. The show was something like a demolition derby, only with very large (car and truck size) heavy duty robots (and explosions and fire). They had a very large Tesla coil they ran as part of the show. One participant was planning to wear a faraday suit, and walk under the coil to draw sparks. I finished my project and left to get dinner before the show, as our human lightning rod was assembling his suit. It had a bird cage for a helmet, and a combination of foil and sheet metal parts. When I came back he was gone, and did not appear in the show. However robots did drive under the coil head (it was about 25' tall and threw massive arcs). When robots drove under it, they typically lasted a few seconds up to 1 or 2 minutes before their electronics became fried, and if they had rubber tires, the arc would pass over the tires and set them on fire. The point being that you might be able to touch a arc from a small coil, but the large ones can start fires and do damage to a person. I speculate the lightning rod boy tested his suit before the show, and found his suit part-to-part coupling was insufficient, and he was probably tasered to the ground as soon as he was struck. It was an impressive coil, but it was so devastating to the robots that it didn't really spend much time on during the show... Not to mention it was extremely loud, and self-destructive if run too long. So just because you can touch the arc from small coils, don't think that you can do it for larger ones. I'm pretty sure that the one at the show was potentially deadly. I don't know how much current it takes to produce the heat required to set a small car tire on fire, but I'm pretty sure it's enough to burn your finger off, and stop your heart too.


When you are close to one of the big ones, the big zzzappp sounds are quite startling. But when people are /trying/ to destroy things, things get out of hand easily. One robot had a 2' diameter sonic canon fueled with oxy-acetylene, and they used it to shoot at targets in the show's field... At one point the driver of the robot pointed it at the stands and sent some people to the emergency room with punctured ear drums... The show was stopped by the police early, and the show's organizers were banned from the state of Texas... and a great time was had by the survivors.

Can someone please explain to me what is low current and why it doesn't kill him? I mean gun has to have high voltage right?

I'm a bit late on this but... The penetration depth of an electrical current is based on the frequency due to the 'skin effect.' A DC current can pass directly through the body and the heart allowing it to easily be deadly. However, in the case of AC current the current density decreases with increasing depth below the surface and the higher the frequency the greater the effect. As Tesla coils use very high frequencies, the current density is exponentially decreasing under your skin quickly. As a result, it is unlikely that the current will pass through your heart for small currents like those created by the Tesla coils featured here. Now, that is not to say the high current, high frequency electrocutions do not hurt or won't be deadly.

Even though this was filmed in 2016, I just ran across it the first time today. Ads an electrical engineer (semi-retired) and a Tesla enthusiast, I've worked with Tesla coils before, and this video was an interesting adjunct to my knowledge base.


I noticed with Cameron's Tesla gun that part of his equipment was a grounding pad strapped to the heel of his boot. I recognize that this was absolutely necessary to make it work. After all, Kirchhoff's Law needs to be obeyed. The video does show that while the visible arc does terminate at some point, that's only the extent of the ionized air particles as plasma. The current of that streamer continues to ground (and, incidentally, to his heel contact pad and on to his backback generator) to complete the circuit.

There is an explanation why you don't get electrocuted by these sparks: the frequency. Primary coil and capacitor make up a resonant circuit that resonates at several kHz or up to MHz. And currents with such high frequencies try to stay at the surface of a conductor (this time: your bidy). So the current flows through your skin to the ground, and does not enter your body - other than a true lighting bolt, which is DC. Look up skin effect for this.

Look up "Skin Effect". (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Skin_effect) No, not your skin: the "skin" of a wire. At high frequencies, local induction forces most of the current to flow near the surface in a predictable "skin" depth. But then again, at high frequencies YOU act like a wire, and most of the current flows along YOUR skin. So these currents don't reach your heart to any significant degree. Also, if you aren't feeling an electric shock, then your heart is feeling even much less. Most of what you feel from this coil is a tiny burn.

I built something like this a few years ago, minus the circuit to make it non-lethal. It was also a bit more powerful. Needless to say, it was designed so the arc was emitted far far far far away from me. Super dangerous and stupid all the same. I ended up blowing a circuit - my math was not quite right. I am going to be building another one, only this time I have an idea involving fully automatic rapid fire c02 projectiles to carry the beam. Although I might just incorporate a separate a set of coils to fire a machine fed, very long string of tethered iron rods at high speed. I am sure many will take note of some technical problems with this, but I am working on that.
EDIT: If I can shrink the electronics enough, or at least effectively distribute the weight, I am considering a small propane powered engine directly into the backpack to generate electricity so I am not tethered to an outlet. Or perhaps something that can be mounted on four wheeler.

The most fun Tesla coil was the large one at the LA Griffith Park observatory, about 8 ft. tall. Seriously noisy, even behind the glass window.I think it's long gone but I haven't been there for years.

My own Junior High School (1945 time frame) Tesla coil used auto glass and aluminum foil in a tray of motor oil for the high voltage capacitor.  The spark gap that worked best was a series of bent nails in a board, a multi-gap gap.  When I took the spark to my body I used a piece of metal because a direct spark to the skin hurt.
I think the "spark gap" is where the radiation goes out for the wireless power transmission?  The coils I think are like a transformer to boost the voltage.

Ahh what the heck, on the actual Tesla coils out there the wiring as well as the dome are all circular in nature. From spark gap to a circular coil as in figure drawing shown at 1:16 in the video. Ok now imagine the "coils" in other geometric shapes. Try that in a few different shapes and see what you get. The lightning bolts CAN be controlled. With a circular coil and other circular parts in the system the lightning is more erratic and less stable. I have no videos of this proof at this time, but i encourage you to try different set ups to see what the differences are that i speak of.

Tesla invented many many innovations we use to this day. Two of the biggest would be WIFI and the incandescent bulbs. The thing about the two is Tesla never wrote or linked the two together that we are aware of other than in house testing in his lab, but he did state that his inventions would not need the use of modern known power lines and transformers. He was also a master in terms of radio waves and understanding them. His idea was to send power via radio waves (see HAARP antenna array) and some even believe it can control the weather or disrupt it in some way. Personally after almost 20 years of studying Tesla and this type of science i have come to find that Tesla kept some things to himself after the debacles with Eddison. I am sure that there are things he never documented just fr the sole purpose of it falling into the wrong hands.

I liked your video for many reasons - 1) Wearing your hat the right way 2) You seemed like a normal bloke, just very enthusiastic, not some cool talkin poser - I hate those guys 3) Anyone who appreciates Tesla, the guy, has my approval - 4) I learned something - I'm an old (UK) electrician who's learned to be respectful of high voltages and so called low voltages too, because the power distribution system delivers enough current to barbecue a human instantly - which sadly happened to a colleague when I was an apprentice  - cleaning out a HV bus-bar chamber thinking it was low - medium voltage, 415V, not 11KV or 3.3kv or whatever - Arced across and a terrible way to die, only recognisable by his ring apparently.   So I cringed seeing you let this thing zap you - I wouldn't have the nerve, despite knowing the current was low.   Hopefully, no-one is naive enough to THINK they can do the same with high voltage power lines or low - medium voltage industrial or domestic supply - But I've seen so many idiots treating it as casually as changing torch batteries - unafraid - unafraid because they don;t know how close they are to having molton metal explode in their face in a three phase flash-over.    A few educational videos of sub-stations exploding when people operate the huge breakers (the oil cooled/ quenching kind) too slowly would be interesting to see again and a reminder of the unseen power in those thin "wires".   It's HARD not equating huge arcs with danger - It's HARD to accept that most electrocution deaths are unspectacular, people just slump to the ground when as little as 50mA stops their heart.  ANYWAY!  on a more cheerful note!  You made a GREAT video here!  Thanks!

I am an Observational Artist, I have spent years documenting the visual world into flat imagery which contains depths and space just like how we perceive the world through our eyes. In Canada we consider anything more than 5 micro amps to be dangerous, and I think a Tesla coil averages 23 Milli amps. Think of current as speed. Slows down to the point you see the arcs longer. It also depends where you are touching. He had insulated boots, for one. Energy takes the path of least resistance. We also use the earth because of its mass, to ground virtually everything. When he touches something with his left hand and not his right, the path of least resistance will generally not involve his heart, the current will go from hand to foot. But when you touch live circuits with both your left and right, the path of least residence is from one hand, across your chest and heart, to the other end and back into the circuit, completing it and allowing for continuous shock

The correct question in Job 38: 36 should be, what gives wisdom to the inner parts and understanding to the mind, no who. Assuming that it was a someone is silly and useless until you have some evidence that it even could be a someone. We know that the brain works like it does because of natural processes developed over a long time in a natural way, so the evidence suggests that it developed naturally. Re: Getting zapped

Besides the low current, the tesla coil's output is RF (Radio Frequency.) Because of that, the current doesn't penetrate. Due to the skin effect, the current travels along the outside of the conductor.

This is good and bad. On the good side, it is unlikely to pass through your heart. On the bad side, the current is concentrated and can cause serious heating.

Ham radio operators and others that work with high power RF need to be cautious, lest they receive RF burns.

Brings back my grade-school science fair project... a solid-state Tesla coil made with a couple MJ3055s and a reclaimed flyback transformer from an old Magnavox 25" color TV.

I made lightning in a 6" clear globe vanity light bulb and made fluorescent tubes light up held in my hand... and I was 12 years old. I felt like a god with the power of the universe itself in my hand. ;)

I also made a Jacob's ladder from an old oil-fired furnace ignition coil and copper wire. I imagine this generation will never know that simple joy; those coils are no longer readily available from any junkyard as they were in my day, and neither are neon sign transformers.

I've seen folks make them using a microwave transformer, but those generate dangerous levels of current (How much? Enough to cook a turkey, or to cook your heart muscle in your chest!!!) and only 3-6KV, so they don't start properly.

The thing you need to keep in mind about secondary coil arcs hitting your skin is that, while the amps is low the energy his high. 10 or 100's of watts.  So while it often doesn't have the current to cause you dangerous electric shocks it does discharge lots of heat in the arc.  The arc can burn deep into your skin called a deep tissue burn. This isn't fatal but takes ages to heal. Holding a metal object and letting the arc hit that spreads out the contact area onto your skin and reduces the problem.

Great video! Just wanted to comment on the nature of the current in the sparks for those interested, as the details are often misrepresented or completely wrong. First of all, the spark current is quite significant, approximately 3-4 amperes peak (yes amps, not milli or micro amps), with a duration of some 10's of milliseconds depending on the settings of the machine. The reasons that it does not cause any noticeable harm is 2 fold: the frequency of the current is around 420kHz, and the discharge has a relatively low charge available by design. The high frequency phenomena is analogous to not being able to hear sounds above a certain frequency because it's too fast for our nervous system to "respond" to. However, anyone who has touched the sparks of a large Tesla coil will know that it still packs a nasty punch, and the reason for this is that the initial connection delivers a significant amount of charge (volts * capacitance) which you will feel. This type of Tesla coil works at a relatively low voltage of 70kV and uses a relatively small self capacitance (the silver donut "toroid" makes up this capacitance mostly) of just 15pF. It's the initial discharge of the 70kV*15pF = 1uC that can cause a "shock" sensation (which is on the order of a static zap of 10kV at 100pF of body capacitance), but the follow through current of 3-4 amps does not cause nerve stimulation (consider an electrocauterization machine that works with similar currents and frequencies, and does not shock the patient). The danger of radio-frequency burns is still significant, however, and there is a nerve response to the intense heating produced where the spark connects to your skin!

I had privilege to indirectly touch the arc from the tesla coil. The trick was to hold a metal stick in you hand. Occasionally a small spark would happen between the hand and the metal stick, but nothing that would hurt you. You could also hold a fluorescent bulb in the other hand and it would glow as it was connected to AC mains. A friend got hit directly into the hand from a giant Tesla coil (he was in the metal cage) but the tip of his finger was outside and he described the pain as someone hitting you with a sharp needle. I figured it must hurt decently since he stopped laughing the rest of the day. (LOL!)

Man. Between you and Grant, I am overwhelmed with nostalgia.

I remember my first time with Tesla. The early morning sun was low on the horizon on the South East side of Guam as we stood in the playground of M.U. Luhan elementary school in Yoña. As my science teacher and her friend from the University of Guam fiddled with the Tesla Coil, I was looking out to sea; looking over the Challenger Deep, which we had learned about the week before when one of the scientist gave us a presentation on the subject.

After a few minutes, a couple of fans whirred to life and our teacher ushered us to the jungle gym, which would act as a Faraday cage for safety. A countdown was started.

The switch was flipped, making a loud "CLACK" and a hum filled the air as the sky broke open with a cloudless thunder storm... It was glorious.

MAN, my childhood was awesome... I mean, aside from the bullies, that is.

PAH!


Not this one. This isn't some childish made-up sci-fi GARBAGE about an idiotic "Back to the future" device which is an oversized TOY, it's not a "hoverboard" that over-promises and MASSIVELY under-delivers (if AT ALL)... stopppp, no more of that kiddy nonsense!!

Nope, this is REAL HONEST SCIENCE - simple physics giving out HUGE emotional reactions because the wow factor is PHYSICS, and physics is NATURE, and since our Lord God designed physics and natural laws, THAT is why the wow factor blows you away - because it's SIMPLE, awesome (the TRUE meaning of that diluted word) and because it's REAL, and HERE, and it's not overly complicated... just NATURAL SCIENCE!

I love tesla coil speakers, but the lack of bass response (even with big coils) is a let down. They would be a lot cooler if they had some "thump". I think that is inherent in the fact that the electric ark is essentially a line that gets longer and shorter, but maybe I'm wrong?

What I see as a possible solution to this is to create an addressable grid of contacts and multiple spark generators, so you can have a CIRCLE of sparks that swells and shrinks, which should create a large moving wave front in the plane of the circle. Seems like there's probably some major flaws and a lot of complexity... any better ideas?

Wait a minute, the well known problem with a "Tesla Gun" like this is its accuracy, that's the main reason that we don't actually make handheld lightning guns like this. Then I remembered about Laser-Induced Plasma Channels and how it creates a pathway of plasma around laser beam, that pathway then ionizes the surrounding air and makes plasma and since that channel now conducts electricity way better than the non-ionized air that is around it the electricity will travel down the channel and hit where the channel ends. So why couldn't we just make a gun like this guy and add a Laser-Induced Plasma Channel emitter to it? In theory shouldn't that make a functional Tesla Lightning gun that is moderately accurate?

Along with being low current the high frequency of the current also causes a skin effect where the current doesn't pass through the whole conductor but only through its surface. As a result, the Tesla coil's current is only passing through your skin, most of it doesn't reach the heart. The high frequency can cause nerve damage though.

There's some things that are wrong in the video:
1) Tesla did not discover the rotating magnetic field. It was confirmed decades before he was born.
2) Tesla was not the first to make a functioning AC motor. He was the first to make an induction motor (probably).
3) the motor Tesla is standing on a 3 phase induction motor, which is misleading since he worked on two-phase induction motors

Hi Destin. First of all, thank you SO much for the videos you put up for us. They are fun and informative and I have learned a great deal from them. I'm sure a lot of others have, too.

Second, after watching this video I felt I just had to comment. I have always thought you were one of the coolest Youtubers out there, and this video proved it. You are highly intelligent and funny and your videos are always upbeat and you have tons of energy, and it's easy to get caught up in your enthusiasm for the topic of each video. I think this is my new favorite on the list of your vids (previously it was the one on Prince Rupert drops, because.... c'mon, I mean - it's about PRINCE RUPERT DROPS and has high speed footage of them shattering!!!). When you became incredulous and overexcited and laughing like a little kid, it was kind of infectious. I began laughing, too. It was so cool to see you get your geek on and to see the wonder and excitement in your eyes build from the beginning of the video, and when you got to shoot the Tesla Gun, you seemed like a little boy that just found out magic was real. When I got to the end, I immediately watched the whole video again, laughing the whole time. It was wonderful. It does the heart good to see one of the cool kids let his inner nerd bubble over. You are a marvel, Sir, and one can easily see why you became a scientist. The Ol' Blister (my pet name for the love of my life - she calls me The Curmudgeon) is already asleep, but I can't wait to show her the video in the morning. Keep up the good work, Sir. Thank you, and God bless you.
